summary:
Okay, here's a summary of my experiences with depression, written from my perspective:

I was diagnosed with bipolar disorder, which has been tough to manage, especially since I choose not to take medication. I've been on many medications in the past, but I felt like they were just experimenting with me and none of them really worked for me in the long run. I prefer to cope with life using my own skills. Even though I don't medicate, I still experience the same anxieties and problems. I get irritated easily and don't like being around people, especially in crowds or with obnoxious individuals. Lately, I've been sleeping too much and have racing thoughts, especially concerning my job search. When I don't sleep well, I dwell on these things. I used to go to therapy weekly, and it helped me to get my anger and thoughts out. I miss it, but I stopped going due to financial reasons, as I don't have health insurance.

summary:
Okay, here's my story with depression, in my own words:

I've struggled with depression for years, officially diagnosed about three or four years ago. But honestly, I think I've always felt it to some degree. It got to a point where I realized my mood just wasn't right. I felt constantly down, lacked energy, wanted to sleep all the time, and lost interest in things. My appetite was either nonexistent or completely out of control.

Recently, things have been even harder. My sister passed away six months ago, and just two weeks ago, I became homeless and jobless. There was a point where I just missed her so much that I wanted to be with her. My family isn't really a support system, so I feel like I'm completely on my own.

I used to find therapy helpful, but now I don't have health insurance, so it's not an option. It's tough because I feel like I don't have anyone to talk to. I even tried to commit suicide once, instead of returning back to my corporate job. Now, I'm just trying to pick up the pieces.

I've been feeling really down because I can't find a job, even though I've been applying everywhere. It makes it hard to sleep, especially with things like car payments looming. I was feeling happy a couple of days ago because I was getting callbacks for jobs, but I don't have the money to stay in LA long enough to follow through. So, I'm hitting the road again.

California.

Yes.

Um, the weather.

Fear of earthquakes.

Psychology.
Cool, are you still working on that?
I am, I go to Harbor College.

I am. I wish I would have went sooner, but better late than never.

Probably I'm not sure, I never really thought about it. I want to work in the field of psychology. But I'm not sure if I want to work with children or adults. So I haven't really decided.

No.
Why?
I don't know. I just don't. Maybe once a year.

June actually, I went to Orlando, Florida.
Awesome, do you consider yourself an introvert?
Sometimes.
But not as relaxed I'm sorry What do you do to relax?
Watch TV, read a book, talk on the phone.
What are some things that make you really mad?
Mad?
My mom gets in my business. Other than that, I guess just frustrations with my son.
Do you find it easy to be a parent?
No.
What's the hardest thing about being a parent?
The hardest thing is raising a child with a disability. Not knowing how you can help him.
That sounds really hard.
It is, it's very hard. I don't sugarcoat it at all.
What's the best thing about being a parent?
Just having my children, they're a blessing, I love them. With all the good and the bad, it's a part of me. I just love the fact that I'm helping mold them into good human beings.
How close are you to your family?
We're really close. My family's small, we live within blocks of each other. But yeah, we're close.
Okay What's one of your most memorable experiences? Good or bad. What comes to your mind?
Most memorable? Just giving birth for the first time. It was just amazing. My son is nine now, so I still remember it like it was yesterday.
How did you feel in that moment?
Like I was being born again myself. I don't know how to explain it. It's just very emotional.
Okay Is there anything you regret?
I don't know. I guess I have a lot of regrets. But none that I really want to mention. I guess I understand.

Stay in school. Don't get emotionally involved. And let people deter you from your goals.

Oh yeah, definitely.
Did you want me to... I'm okay I'm okay, I mean, I'm pretty easy going. For the most part I don't really have a temper per se. Things frustrate me more than they anger me.

Oh, that's easy. With my mother, she's like I guess the argument stemmed from me wanting to socialize. She feels that I'm married with children. So I should stay at home like 99% of the time. But she gets kind of intrusive, I don't know.

Oh, I know. After the semester ended when I noted that I did well in school. Because it had been a long time since I went to school. So when I received my grades, A and a B, I was like, wow, okay I can do this. And it made me happy. And that was about a few weeks ago, I guess.
That's great.
Thank you.
There's some of it that's been impossible to do. There's some of it that's been a positive influence in your life.

Thank you.
Yes.

I don't know. I never really thought about it. I guess it's just, you know, being around my kids. You know, I just love being around my children. That always puts me in a good mood.
Thank you.
Okay, like I said, a little tired, you know, but You know, for the most part, okay. But I wake up early as well, so It's kind of like Get in bed a little bit, I go to bed at like 8, 8.30 And then I wake up at like 1, 1.30 So Very moody Very irritable, short tempered, I guess. Thank you.
No.
Occasionally.

Okay.
No problem.
Bye.

summary:
Okay, here's a summary of my experiences with depression, written from my perspective:

I wouldn't say I'm currently depressed, but I have dealt with feeling guilty, sad, or depressed about my son's disability in the past. Now, I'm actively trying to think more positively and find resources to help him instead of dwelling on negative emotions. I also get very moody, irritable, and short-tempered when I don't get enough sleep. I go to bed early, around 8 or 8:30 PM, but I also wake up very early, around 1 or 1:30 AM.

summary:
Okay, here's a summary of my experiences with depression, from my perspective:

I was diagnosed with depression back in 1980 after my father, who was a psychiatrist, noticed some symptoms. I wasn't sleeping well, I was laying around the house all day, waking up late, and I lacked focus, especially when it came to finding a job. I even remember going to job interviews and then not being able to bring myself to go inside.

I went to therapy for about three years, and my psychiatrist eventually felt I was doing much better. I did get to a much better place, but I know I have to constantly monitor myself for signs of slipping back. I still have good days and bad days. Therapy helped me see depression as a filter, like wearing "depression sunglasses" that distort your perception. I try to consciously remove those glasses and double-check if I'm seeing things accurately or through a depressed viewpoint.

Lately, I feel like I'm slipping back a bit, especially during periods of unemployment. I've noticed in the past that a lack of structure makes it easy to fall back into sleeping too late and procrastinating. Structure is really important for me; it gets me out of bed, forces me to be on time, and requires me to interact with people, all of which are beneficial. I've also noticed I've been focusing on negative things, like reading about ancient battles or watching shows about animal attacks.

One of my biggest regrets is not finishing college. I think I was already struggling with depression in my senior year and wasn't coping well. I wish I had sought therapy and outside help with the logistics of getting through finals, especially since I was an art major without a car. Looking back, it would have been worth it to do whatever it took to get a car at that time.

summary: I was diagnosed with depression about six years ago, but I think I've suffered from it my whole life. I'm a creative person, and I've always had my highs and lows, just feeling "blah" and bored. Lately, though, it's been worse than ever. I'm just in survival mode. I went to a free clinic and they offered medication, but I didn't want to take it. I don't like medication. I wasn't really into therapy either. The therapist just confirmed I was depressed and maybe bipolar, but I figured I'd just deal with it. To cope, I go to free events every night to shut out life, spending time in movie theaters to block everything out.

summary: Okay, here's my experience with depression. While I haven't been formally diagnosed with depression, I've definitely had struggles that have impacted my mental well-being. A few years ago, I had a heart attack related to stress. Looking back, I recognize that my compulsive gambling was a major issue. It stemmed from working long hours under a lot of stress and it became a way to cope. It led to significant financial problems and a breakdown of trust with my wife, ultimately contributing to the end of my marriage. I felt immense guilt and like less than a human being when the extent of my gambling came to light. I wouldn't say I feel "down" now, but I do have regrets about the pain I caused and the career I ruined. Now I focus on taking things one day at a time, trying to be at peace, meditating, and doing things that help me stay healthy and avoid those past behaviors. I think of it as a recovery process.

transcript:
Okay, great.

Hi, I'm Ellie. Thanks for coming in today. I was created to talk to people in a safe and secure environment. I'm not a therapist, but I'm here to learn about people and would love to learn about you. I'll ask a few questions to get us started. And please feel free to tell me anything. Your answers are totally confidential. Are you okay with this?
Yes.
So, how are you doing today?
I'm okay. I'm a little pensive, I guess. A little down, but more or less okay.
Where are you from originally?
I was born in Annapolis, Maryland on the East Coast.
Why did you move to LA?
Originally, I moved because I went to film school. But then I decided to come, I moved back to Washington, DC to do some work and now I'm back here again.
How easy was it for you to get used to living in LA?
It's very different being from the East Coast. It just has a different feel to it. But living LA has a very different kind of attitude, I guess. And so it's a little difficult, but I've gotten more used to it since I've been here.
How often do you go back to your hometown?
Not at all. When I left, things got sort of, I lost my job out there and so I had to move out here kind of quick to be with some people who were going to help me out and I'm just kind of not really speaking to my family or old friends that often.
How hard is that?
It's not easy. I miss a lot of people. I miss my old life before I lost my job. I miss some friends. I miss a lot of the relationships that I had out there. So it's difficult. I mean it weighs on my mind a lot. I feel like I failed and now I'm here and I can't seem to get back on my feet. So it's hard.
Do you consider yourself more shy or outgoing?
Depends on the situation. I think I'm outgoing when I'm comfortable and then I'm extremely outgoing but when I'm in a situation I'm not comfortable with I tend to be a lot more shy.
Okay.
What do you do to relax?
I do a lot of writing. I have certain music that I listen to as I'm writing and when I can get really into that and shut out the rest of the world the music and the thoughts happening really soothes me. It's when I feel most relaxed.
When was the last time that happened?
A few weeks ago I guess I've been working on a book, on a novel and when I was really getting into writing it and it was really working for me that was good. That was really good. I felt like I was accomplishing something and I felt really relaxed. It was about a guy who was searching for something. It's his last day on earth and so he's going to find a person that he met and just was so struck by that he needs to find her and spend the last few minutes he has on earth with her. Just because. It's sort of romantic adventure comedy kind of thing.
How did you decide to do that?
I've been meaning to write a novel but I was just waiting for the idea to really hit me.
How hard is that?
It's not easy. The parts when it's good it's really good but getting there is sometimes a real struggle. I find it difficult. I have a real love-hate relationship with writing. When I love it I just absolutely love it. But sometimes I hate it because it's so difficult. But it's worth it for the times when it's good.
How are you at controlling your temper?
Good. I don't really have a temper. Most of my anger that I have is directed inward as opposed to outward to other people. If something is really stressful or if I'm in a situation like a very intense confrontation I can lose it. But that's probably only happened to me three or four times in my whole life. Generally I pretty much try to when I'm upset I get upset with myself not with other people.
When was the last time you argued with someone and what was it about?
Last night I guess I got in an argument about whether or not cleaning vegetables was necessary because of I forget. It was about whether you can clean vegetables after you cut them because I had already started cutting the vegetables and I thought that would be okay. So it turned into this big argument and we did Google searches to figure out who was right and who was wrong and I ended up being wrong on that one. But it is yeah that was it wasn't a blow up argument but it was a definite argument.
What's something you feel guilty about?
A lot so much. I was in a relationship that I really wanted to work and I ended up and it was partly due to I wasn't on the right medication and so I was going like everything sort of spiraled out of control and I feel really guilty about the way that that ended. I wasn't mean but I was getting more and more messed up and I couldn't stop it and it ended and so I feel really guilty about not doing enough and making her have to tell me that she never wanted to see me again. So that was pretty tough.
Can you have done anything to avoid it?
Well some of it was that I wasn't medicated properly. I mean now I've been to a doctor and I'm on medication that's completely kind of I mean I still get upset and I still get depressed but it's not like it was. It's not I don't completely lose it for days at a time. So I mean I know there's a part of me that knows logically that it wasn't all my fault and that if I had if I had been able to deal with the chemicals in my brain then it would have probably been different. If I was who I am now then I would have been it probably would have gone very differently or maybe it wouldn't have but I mean I could have I don't know I don't know if I could have done anything different. Things being how they were.
I think that maybe you're being a little hard on yourself.
I mean it's possible. I mean obviously yeah because I mean that's what I do. I take little things and I just think about them all the time in my head until it drives me crazy. I dwell on stuff. And it's like any little detail that comes up I suddenly remember and it can just throw me off for a whole day. I mean I still get really uncomfortable and embarrassed and feel ashamed about stuff that I did in high school which was years and years ago which I shouldn't even be thinking about anymore because it's so in the past but I still get that feeling like I'm right back there. Yeah.
That sounds really hard.
Well it's not easy. I've been trying to figure out ways to deal with it. I mean I dealt with it for a long time by drinking and you know just trying to slow my mind down that way. But you know since the medication it's been better. It hasn't been impossible to deal with. It hasn't been easy but it's been better.
That's good. How do you cope with them?
Well like I said I do a lot of you know if I'm if I'm writing or if I'm doing anything like I kind of have to almost be doing two things at once to occupy my brain completely. Um if I'm watching TV I have to be playing a game on my phone. If I'm using the computer I have to be you know watching a TV show or a movie on you know in another window so that I can just keep my mind occupied during all that. I just need I mean I wish that I could just sort of let the thoughts come and deal with them but I just I can't yet.
Are they triggered by something?
They're triggered by everything. Pretty much anything that I see. If I hear somebody with a Dutch last name if I hear somebody talk about Wisconsin if I hear you know people talk about just anything you know I can reach back and connect to this. It's really I don't know. That's the thing. I mean I don't ever get a break from it. Yeah.
How easy is it for you to get a good night's sleep?
I'm a very light sleeper so I'm awake and asleep and awake and asleep. I have no problem going back to sleep but I generally don't know. I'd never really needed much sleep. So it's just only recently that I've really started to feel the effects of not getting enough sleep. Like I would usually stay up until two or three in the morning so that I could just be so exhausted that I would just conk out and wake up the next day and feel fine go to work. But now it's like if I do that I can't I still don't get enough sleep. I don't know. I get up, I toss and turn all night. You know and now it's yeah I don't sleep too great right now.
What are you like when you don't sleep well?
It's hard to know. I usually just kind of power through it and just I'm like how I am now. I just feel bad.
Okay. How long ago were you diagnosed?
I think three, three, four years ago. It was when I had been given taken stuff for anxiety for years before that. But then I finally got a psychiatrist who actually sat down and talked to me and said you've actually got this situation. We need to get you on the medication that you're on is not working. You need to get on this new medication that will actually start to even you out and heal you a little bit from all this. So yeah that was kind of a turning point. But unfortunately it happened after everything went bad.
How did you feel in that moment?
Looking back on it I feel it really makes me angry. It really makes me given where I am right now it makes me really angry that I lost everything because of chemicals in my brain and I lost everything because of chemicals in my brain because of things that I couldn't control and that the people that were supposed to help me weren't helping me. I mean I was paying a lot of money to go see doctors and they were doing they it didn't help it didn't work until I managed to find somebody who did work and I just yeah so I'm like thanks guys for helping but it was a little late now
What got you to say help?
There really wasn't any choice I had to. I was a mess. It was either I was self-medicating or I was affecting my work everything was just there was a point where I really realized that I just had to make this different but again it was too late because then my review came up a few months later and after being institutionalized once or twice and all this stuff they just decided that I was just not worth keeping around so they laid me off. But it was at least that and not firing me. But so I got help but it wasn't soon enough. Not as much as I should.
I go to a couple of meetings so that I can keep control of that aspect and there's a therapy aspect to that. Unfortunately being unemployed my employment ran out I'm getting my medication from the city of L.A. So I'm not really in a position to put money into seeing somebody. Somebody so I have a psychiatrist that I go see but it's really very I've only seen her three times in the past year. So it's basically to keep my medication coming. And then there's you.
Right.
Just saying stuff out loud is like getting the stuff out. Trying to figure out how to take that mess that's in your stomach and in your brain and make it into words and sentences that make sense. That you can actually deal with is a big step like regardless of who you're saying it to whether it's a therapist or just a room full of drugs you're taking all that stuff that's really been killing you and you're making it into something that you can do. Something that you can write down something that you can talk about as opposed to just letting it just sit there as this formless thing.
It's sort of it has its ups and downs. You know I'm applying for jobs five six jobs or more a day and never getting a response never getting an interview never even getting close to being self sufficient again. It's hard but that's like real world problems I feel like the chemical parts are getting under control like the depression is getting under control. So now it's just I have to deal with real life which is It has its own challenge.
Yeah.
It can be tough to find a good job.
Yeah. Tell me about the last time you felt really happy.
It was probably a couple of years ago. The thing that immediately comes to mind is everything was going well at my job. I was making these great videos with this person that I was having a relationship with and we were really close we were having fun together and we went out and got a Christmas tree. And we spent all this time picking out the perfect Christmas tree and it was just feeling like a part of somebody's life and feeling like a part of the bigger bigger life that's out there you know like what normal people feel. You know for that instant I felt like a normal person doing a normal thing with a pretty girl who he really really liked a lot and everything was going really well. I mean it wasn't going really well because it was all messed up but for that instant I felt like a normal person a normal happy person and Part of what makes it so hard now is knowing that I don't know if I'll ever feel that again. So.
What are you most proud of?
Probably the educational video series I did for the National Science Foundation. It was really hard and it would but in the end it turned out really good and you know I'm hoping that it helps a lot of kids and it helps the world with getting kids excited about science and about the world around them so that I feel like that was a really good thing to do. It was part of my job. It was an interesting life. We were trying to come up with new ideas for because we would put together videos and stuff to give to schools and everything and they had done those before but we decided to do something really big you know and there was a lot of traveling and there was a lot of and so it was probably the biggest project that the NSF has decided to do and so we just kind of produced it.
Okay.
I think I've asked everything I need to. Thanks for sharing your thoughts with me. Goodbye.
Thank you. Howdy. Bye.
summary:
Okay, here’s a summary of my experiences with depression, from my perspective:

I've been dealing with depression for a few years, though I was initially treated only for anxiety. Looking back, I'm angry because I feel like I lost everything – my job, relationships, my old life – due to a chemical imbalance in my brain that wasn't properly addressed. I sought help and saw doctors, but it wasn’t effective until I found a psychiatrist who correctly diagnosed me and prescribed the right medication.

Before that, things spiraled out of control, especially in a past relationship that I feel guilty about because I wasn’t medicated properly. Now, the medication helps me manage things. I still get upset and depressed, but I don’t completely lose it for days like I used to.

I still struggle with dwelling on things, even things from high school. I used to self-medicate with alcohol to slow my mind down, but the medication has helped. I cope by constantly occupying my mind – watching TV while playing games, or using the computer while watching a show. My thoughts are triggered by everything, and it feels like I never get a break. I'm also a light sleeper, which doesn’t help.

Currently, I attend meetings for support and have access to a psychiatrist through the city, but only see her a few times a year to keep my medication coming. Talking about my feelings, even to a program like this, helps me process and externalize the mess in my head. The chemical parts of my depression are getting under control, but now I'm facing real-world challenges like unemployment and struggling to become self-sufficient again. I remember a time a few years ago when everything was going well, and I felt like a normal, happy person. I don't know if I'll ever feel that way again.

And I actually have good relations with everybody, I think. I think I have a ton of family and friends that get along with me pretty well, actually. Yeah. There are times when it's pretty easy for me to go to sleep. Actually, I feel like I sleep like a baby. The only problem I have, I think, is I feel like sometimes you fall asleep and you have you're just going to sleep and you kind of like joke, you almost kind of like fall. It's like a falling sensation or something like that. It doesn't happen that often, but it happens. For the most part, I sleep like a rock. I sleep really good. That's good. What have you been feeling lately? Well, right now, generally, I've been feeling worried and anxious and tense. The reason why is because I said my mom, at least today, I found out my mom, she didn't tell me the whole story and I'm kind of waiting until this is over so I can find out what's wrong with her. I'm worried about her. She's in the doctors right now, so that doesn't tell me anything good. I'm trying to find a job. So that has me worried too. The baby along the way. So that has me worried. I feel overwhelmed with a lot of things to do and a lot of it doesn't have anything to do with me, but I have to handle it. Yeah. How do you cope with them? Well, I keep myself distracted. I keep myself busy. I feel like a busy body, and the more which kind of seems like it's not a good thing because I feel like I'm just adding more things on my plate. One of the things I do is exercise. I have to work out every day, but that takes an hour to change and start running and go through the whole thing of stretching and cooling down. It takes some time and then to shower and all that kind of stuff takes time. I have to do it daily. So I cope with it in that way. I also cope with it playing guitar. That's just more of a distraction. Keeping busy that way. It just seems like it's not working towards the goals that I need to do is find a job, which I should be doing. It's one of those things where I find there's no good jobs. I've been looking and looking and sometimes when I do, it's just not what I want to do. It just doesn't seem like I want to do these terrible jobs. It's probably harder than I'm thinking about it because sometimes I feel like it is hard, but it's not. There are ways I can cope with it. I just got to kind of accepted it a lot, internalized it. It's not something that's I'm not out on the streets or anything like that. It is a worry. I've never been diagnosed with PTSD. The last time I was really happy, I feel like nothing makes me happy no more. I learned a new song on the guitar. I feel like not even happy about that. I work out. Sometimes that kind of makes me happy. Running like fast and working out. That doesn't make me so excited or anything like that. It just makes me feel good. I have these times where I'm feeling good about myself, but I'm never feeling great. I'm never feeling happy. I'm never feeling sensationalized. These are old times where there's a few good times and a few bad times, but the good times are never extremes, never really good times and never really atrocious bad times. What are some things you wish you could change about yourself? Well, I wish this diet would work out a little bit better because I'm the kind of guy who just likes rice and Mexican food and snacks. I feel like I do so much running and so much activity that if I got my diet in check, that would go a long way. I wish I also can change my desire to get ahead right now. I feel just so like the economy is so bad and things are so rough that it's pointless to even look for these kind of jobs. I just wish I had a little bit more inspiration and a lot more motivation to do things. Is there anything you regret? The one thing I regret is this LSAT thing, not canceling the test to begin with, because I'm sure I could have gone into school. But then again, it has me thinking, do I really want to pay a bunch of law school tuition and the cost of that just to be powered down with more work and things like that? There is this idea of justice and republicanism and things that I really adhere to that I fall in love with that I don't want to get away from. It just seems like it's a ton of work and money just for the small percentage of success that you might not be able to do in that kind of field. I would tell myself maybe I think I've done everything really well for myself, except for the LSAT thing, which I regret on one hand and the other hand, I'm not sure if I regret because of the bills and all that kind of stuff. I've waited to get married. I waited to have a kid. I've been pretty cautious about this. I don't take drugs. I don't drink. I don't fight. I don't do any of these things that I think that real people have and they really ruin their life. I'm pretty happy and content with being cautious. Okay. How would your best friend describe you? Oh, my best friend. I think he kind of likes me. He wishes that I would do more things with him, but he works at night. I think most people, not just my best friend, but my wife and my rest of my family feel that I don't put a lot of time and attention to them. I don't know if I really can give them a real shoulder to cry on or if they ask for something, I'll usually do it, but I almost feel like it's like a chore. If they really need me, then I'll do it. If they're just asking for a favor, I almost feel I do it with a lot of lackluster, a lot of half-hardness. It's not because I hate them or anything. I really like them. In times like I don't want to let them down. They are my friends, but at the same time, I just feel like it's more of like a chore to do instead of a willingness. It's just something that I do because I kind of have to. You got to do things for your friends in the end because they're your friends. In the end I do like them and they probably would do it for me. So I just do these things. Well, there are a couple of things that I do like that I feel good about myself. I ran the LA marathon. That kind of feels good. I graduated from college. That kind of feels good. The thing is, I don't feel like that proud of myself for those things alone. Graduating from college hasn't really made me successful. summary:
Okay, here's my summary of my experiences with depression, written from my perspective:

Lately, I've been feeling worried, anxious, and tense. A lot of it stems from my mom's health issues, which are stressing me out. Job hunting is also a major source of anxiety. The baby on the way adds to the feeling of being overwhelmed. I try to cope by keeping myself busy, exercising, and playing guitar, but it feels more like a distraction than a real solution. 

The problem is, nothing really makes me happy anymore. Even when I achieve something, like learning a new song or having a good workout, the joy is fleeting. I feel good sometimes, but I'm never truly *happy* or excited. My life feels like a mix of okay times and okay-bad times, but nothing is ever extremely good or extremely bad. I wish I could feel inspired and motivated again. The last time I was really happy is so far back I can barely remember it.

transcript:
Okay. All right. Thanks. Go ahead.

How are you doing today?
I'm okay.

Where are you from originally?
I grew up in Wisconsin, and I lived in Colorado for a bit, and then I lived overseas for a little while, and then I moved to California.

When'd you move to LA?
June of last year so I guess it's been eight months something like that.

How often do you go back to your hometown?
At the most probably twice a year.

How does it compare to LA?
Well my hometown is all of 5,000 people and there are a lot of cows and barns and farms so the opposite of LA.

Why do you miss LA?
It's a good question. I've always wanted to live in California but I had been living in the central coast and I just have been coming down to LA like once a month for different business and networking and personal development stuff so yeah things were changing in Santa Cruz for me. The client I had who was really the main financial source I had that relationship ended so I was totally free to move and I thought well I guess I'll give LA a try and see what happens. So I gave it a shot and here I am.

How easy was it for you that you still live in LA?
No not at all. It's a very very big city. I lived in Dublin in Ireland which is also a big city but European cities are much more condensed and the public transportation is much more easy. So just getting around here and getting familiar with the city was pretty challenging.

Do you travel a lot?
I love to travel. I lived in Ireland and I traveled. I was in Morocco and I was in Costa Rica. I spent some time in Mexico.

What do you enjoy about traveling?
I love meeting new people, experiencing new cultures and also not just seeing what's different but seeing what's similar among people everywhere you go.

I'd love to hear about one of your friends.
Sure. I'm trying to think which was my favorite. There's amazing things about Morocco and Costa Rica both but Morocco was incredible. It was like 12 days and we went to 3 different locations. We went up in the Atlas Mountains which are beautiful. It's a really really cool culture.

What's one of your most memorable experiences?
My most memorable moment of that trip was being on a bus and leaving Dublin and going down to the countryside and seeing how breathtakingly beautiful it is. Everyone sees pictures of Ireland or you see it in films and it's green and lush and gorgeous but you actually get there and experience it. The pictures don't do it justice.

What did you study at school?
I have an undergrad degree in English and Psychology and a psychology minor and I have a masters degree in Women's Studies.

Are you still working on that?
No, I use my English and Psychology. I work in marketing communications. I actually do sales. The psychology definitely comes into play. I guess my undergrad degree in English but really I took that on and created something out of it because most people who get an English degree just teach and I wasn't wanting to teach.

What made you decide to do that?
I guess I'm not clear on the question. Let's come back to that later. I love my job. You could almost say it's virtually made for me.

What's your dream job?
My dream job is being a motivational speaker and trainer and coach and traveling the world doing that and impacting people's lives and really contributing to people.

Tell me about your relationship with your family.
My relationship is pretty good actually. I just repaired my relationship with my biological mother. She was sporadic. I saw her sporadically growing up. My dad raised me and then he married my stepmom and they had two kids together so I grew up and I consider them the family I grew up with. I got in communication with my biological mother last May and we've cleared things up and have been in communication since then.

How did you feel in that moment?
Sometimes when I'm feeling tense I turn on the fish tank screen saver. I know it's not Hawaii but it's the best I've got.

What do you do to relax?
I love to dance. I love to read. I love to go to the ocean and spend time staring at the waves and soaking up all those negative ions. That really recharges my battery actually. Probably more than anything else. I like to be with friends. I love art and trying new restaurants. All those things are both relaxing. I guess they're relaxing in the sense that I feel connected to the people in my life and to the experiences of my life.

How are you at controlling your temper?
Depends. If I'm driving not very good but otherwise I'm pretty good at it.

When was the last time you argued with someone and what were you about?
Last time I argued with somebody. Probably would have to be with the LA Times about the newspaper delivery. The newspaper that was supposed to show up for the elderly lady that I take care of, it didn't show up. I didn't realize that it wasn't there until late afternoon. I think early afternoon. I called them and they said they couldn't send a replacement because it was after 10.30 in the morning which was absurd to me when they made the mistake in the first place. For a service that would pay for it for every day. I was really irritated. I was angry with the LA Times. I was angry with the people who had forwarded the newspaper and didn't tell me. It was pretty frustrating.

Tell me about a situation that you wish you had handled differently.
Oh wow, there are quite a few of those. Let me think about one. The other day I had a phone call and I'm in a coaching program. It was from one of the coaches in the program. She was explaining to me that there was an additional call that was going to be, we have meetings every week, classroom meetings and then we also have coaching calls because we have one particular coach we work with. She called to tell me that I was going to have another coaching call with someone who's not my coach. That hadn't been explained to me as part of the program so in that moment it just seemed to me like oh my god I have all these people I have to be accountable to and I have to not just be accountable to them but share private things that are happening in my life with these people. I just was, I don't know. So, yeah, I wasn't angry. I just felt frustrated and a little overwhelmed in that moment and I talked it out with her and we got through it. Yeah, I could have certainly just been okay with whatever was being asked of me at that time and would have made the call go a lot smoother.

The hardest decision.
Wow, there's been a few. Moving to Ireland was probably the hardest decision. No, it wasn't even the hardest decision. It was such an easy decision actually, but telling my family about it was challenging. The hardest decision was the first time that I moved away from my family. I was 28 and I decided to, I chose to move to Colorado. And that was a pretty tough decision. At that point my family had been within an hour's drive of wherever I lived, an hour, hour and a half, and now they're going to be a 12 hour drive away or a plane ride away. So that was challenging.

What made you decide to do that?
Oh, lots of things. I loved Colorado. Colorado is a beautiful, beautiful state and the weather is so much better than Wisconsin. And at the time I was very much into rock climbing and there's just a huge outdoor community in Colorado. So there were a lot more people who were in my age group and were single. That was another factor. And were interested in the things I was interested in. So Colorado just seemed like a really natural fit. So yeah, and then I found a job that I liked. The pay was atrocious, but I found some work that was really rewarding. So it all came together and I chose to move.

That sounds like a great situation. How easy is it for you to get a good night's sleep?
That's a totally unrelated question. Relatively easily. It just depends on what time I go to sleep. If I'm out and I don't get home until 1130, then I go to bed late and I wake up feeling tired like I feel today. But generally I can sleep through the night. I've had some pretty anxiety ridden dreams the last couple of weeks. But even so, even when I wake up from those or if I stir from those, I still can fall back to sleep relatively easily.

Are they triggered by something?
Yeah, I'm sure they are. I'm in another transition state. I'm moving out of the house that I live in right now where I take care of an elderly woman. I have defined the financial means to support me in doing that. She creates a lot of anxiety in her state of being. She's exhausting and utterly depressing.

How hard is that?
Living with her is pretty hard. It's probably the hardest thing I've ever done. I would never ever choose to do it again. Honestly, if I knew what I was getting into, I don't think I would have said yes to the situation.

How have you been feeling lately?
I feel trapped and helpless. There's no way out of the situation that I'm in. No matter what I do, it doesn't get any better. I'm not getting any kind of work that I want to do. My money's not working at all. It feels pretty crappy.

Have you been diagnosed with depression?
I have in the past.

How long ago were you diagnosed?
A long time ago. I was 15 or 14. It was over 20 years ago.

What got you to see the outcome?
I was suicidal.

Do you feel down?
Oh yeah, I feel down.

Do you still go to therapy now?
I don't actually, no.

Why did you stop?
I originally stopped with my therapist because we had completed. We had worked on what needed to be worked on. I was no longer depressed. Then I began therapy again later on. It was in my early 30s. Then we ended that because I'd moved to Ireland.

Do you feel like therapy's useful?
Yeah, depending on the therapist and depending on your intention. I don't go into therapy thinking, oh, I'm going to be in this therapeutic relationship for the next 10 years. I think that's ridiculous. I think you go into therapy to work on a specific problem and have a solution and have somebody be your sounding board who can see things that you can't see and work through that situation and come up with a strategy for not just that, not just creating a solution in that area, but also just creating strategies and tools for the rest of your life so that you don't have to worry about it.

Tell me about the last time you felt really happy.
Last time I felt really happy. That's pretty sad. It was at least a year ago. No, that's not true. It was when I saw my biological mother, which was last May.

What would you say are some of your best qualities?
My best qualities. I'm strong, very strong-willed. I'm very supportive and loving and nurturing. I'm easy to be around. I'm intelligent.

Is there anything you regret?
Anything I regret? I don't think so. No.

What advice would you give yourself 10 or 20 years ago?
Don't take life too seriously.

Tell me how you spend your ideal weekend.
Oh, my ideal weekend. I spend some time at the beach. I spend some time with friends. Either going out a night to a movie or just going out to a club or a bar, somewhere that we can just sit and chat and be together. Maybe go dancing after. And Sundays I usually go to... And then I have brunch with friends. I go home and Sunday night I get ready for the next day.

What are you most proud of in your life?
I am most proud of a few things. I've moved to places that I wanted to move to. I've done things that have really spoken to me and have meant something, been dear to my heart to actually achieve those goals or those... Yeah, I've done things that I've wanted to do, like move to Ireland and move to California.

Okay. I think I've asked everything I need to. Thanks for sharing your thoughts with me.
Sure. Goodbye. Bye. Just a little bit of a... Finish up with a quick post survey. So...
summary:
Okay, here's my story regarding depression:

I was diagnosed with depression a long time ago, when I was only 14 or 15. It was triggered by feeling suicidal. I did go to therapy then, and it was helpful. I stopped when I felt like we'd worked through the issues and I was no longer depressed. I went back to therapy again in my early 30s, but stopped when I moved to Ireland. I do think therapy can be useful, depending on the therapist and your own intentions. You go in to work on specific problems and find solutions, not to be in therapy for years.

Right now, I'm feeling down. I feel trapped and helpless in my current living situation, taking care of an elderly woman. It's exhausting and utterly depressing. I feel like there's no way out, and no matter what I do, things don't get better. I'm not getting the work I want, and my finances aren't working out. It feels pretty crappy.

summary:
Okay, here's my story regarding my experiences with depression:

Things have been rough lately, especially with sleep. I've had nights with only two to four hours of sleep because I was working on set. Then I have trouble falling asleep. I felt a lot of pressure when I first moved to LA, trying to find a job and meet people. It was overwhelming, but I think I'm slowly getting used to it, though the pressure is still there.

It's hard to remember when I was last truly happy. I think it was during the writing process of a movie I co-wrote, co-directed, and co-produced last year. We had so much creative energy. But when you're making a movie, especially independently, it's hard to allow yourself to be happy. I wish I was less ruled by fear and more fearless in my everyday interactions and zest for living.

summary:
Okay, here's a summary of my experiences with depression, from my perspective:

I haven't been officially diagnosed with depression, but I believe everyone experiences a range of emotions, including depression, happiness, anger, and shyness. It's just that the intensity and frequency vary from person to person. I definitely feel really happy a lot, like this morning when I was biking in the sun. But I also feel really sad a lot too. Lately, I've been cruising on a "gray line," which is stable and comfortable for me. To cope with difficult feelings, I rely on breathing exercises, chamomile tea, and sometimes cannabis. I try to rid myself of bad energy. If I remember to breathe and follow my routines, I can manage my thoughts. If I get caught up in my thoughts, it takes longer to get back on track.

summary: I've been feeling down lately, mostly because I'm struggling financially and don't have a boyfriend. It's been over two years since I felt truly happy, back when I didn't have money problems. Lately, I've just been feeling more sad than usual. While I haven't been diagnosed with depression, it's been hard. I get frustrated because I'm poor and don't want to be. Leaving home to try for a better life in California was a hard decision, and while I miss home, I try to persevere. I find some comfort in small things, like watching my cats play and sometimes turning on a fish tank screensaver when I feel tense.

I'm not a therapist, but I'm here to learn about people and I'd love to learn about you. I'll ask you a few questions to get us started. And please feel free to tell me everything, your answers are fully confidential. Are you okay with this? Yes.
So, how are you doing today? I'm doing well. That's good. Where are you from originally? Uh, California. What are some things you really like about LA? I like the weather, I like the people. What are some things you don't really like about LA? I don't like the traffic. That's primarily it. I see what you mean. What did you study at school? Sociology. Really? Yep. How did you decide to do that? It's a topic that just really interested me, the most out of all the other subjects. Are you still working on that? No. What's your dream job? To be a writer. Can you tell me about that? I like being able to write what I want to write. Right now I write things that I'm not really that interested in. Like what? Like articles about teenager culture, stuff like that. What do you think of today's kids? I think they have it pretty easy. They don't know how easy they have it. Do you travel a lot? No, not really. Do you consider yourself more shy or outgoing? Depends on the situation or who I'm around. When I first meet people I can be shy. But if it's someone I've known for a while I can be outgoing. What do you do to relax? I'll lay down or try some sort of deep breathing. Or just maybe do something that's kind of fun and mind numbing like watch TV. How are you at controlling your temper? I'm pretty good. I don't really let anger show that much. I don't have a fiery temper or anything like that. I'm pretty rational. That's good. When was the last time you argued with someone and what was it about? I actually can't remember when the last time I argued with someone was because it's been so long. Wow. What's something you feel guilty about? I guess I feel guilty about the fact that I don't talk to my grandparents as much as I should. Tell me about your relationship with your family. I'm close with my grandparents, but not really anyone else in my family. Why? Because they basically sort of raised me and my parents weren't really in the picture that much. I understand. Tell me about a situation that you wish you could erase from your memory. Uh... I guess when my sister died it was really traumatizing. I'm sorry. Is it uncomfortable for you to talk about this? Yeah. Yes. Tell me about the hardest decision you've ever had to make. Um... I guess the hardest decision I've ever had to make is deciding whether or not to divorce my husband. What made you decide to do that? Uh... because we weren't getting along and there was no reason to stay married, but I still felt like I should stick it out. How hard is that? Uh... my grandmother was a positive influence from a young age. Can you tell me about that? She's just a very strong, powerful, sort of staunch character and that rubbed off on me. That's so good to hear. How easy is it for you to get a good night's sleep? Uh... not really super easy. I sort of... I mean it's probably my fault I go to bed too late. Fine. No complaints. Have you noticed any changes in your behavior or thoughts lately? No. It's been the same as ever. Have you ever been diagnosed with PTSD? No. Have you been diagnosed with depression? No. Tell me about the last time you felt really happy. Uh... last night I was just hanging out with my friends and was just having like a really good time sharing stories and laughing and stuff. That's great. How are your best friends right now? Uh... probably funny and easy to get along with but also caring. Tell me how you spend your ideal weekend. Uh... I spend my ideal weekend not really doing much. Like maybe just sitting around and reading or going to the movies, watching TV. Is there anything you regret? Uh... no. I don't think. I think regretting things is a waste of time. What advice would you give yourself 10 or 20 years ago? Um... Don't go out of your way to try and impress people. If they like you then they like you. What are some things you wish you could change about yourself? Um... Sometimes I can be kind of lazy. I'd like to have more of a sort of better work ethic I guess. Can you give me an example of that? Uh... just sort of putting off stuff until you know right when it's due or after it's due things like that. procrastinating. Okay. Tell me about a time when someone made you feel really bad about yourself. Uh... sometimes for the things that I write, people will write negative things about me like in the comments section on a website. That'll make me feel bad. That sucks. What would you say are some of your best qualities? I'm articulate and funny and a good friend. What are you most proud of in your life? Um... I guess I'm most proud of the fact that I am satisfied with myself and my friends and my status in the world. I'm proud of the fact that I feel comfortable with it. That's so good to hear. What are some things that usually put you in a good mood? Um... just hanging out with my friends. people watching. Watching a movie that's good. listening to music. Okay. I think I've asked everything I need to. Thanks for sharing your thoughts with me. Goodbye.

transcript:
Okay. Hi, I'm Ellie. Thanks for coming in today. I'm just created to talk to people in a safe and secure environment. I'm not a therapist, but I'm here to learn about people and we love to learn about you. I'll ask a few questions to get us started. And please feel free to tell me anything. Your answers are fully confidential. Are you okay with this?
Yes. I'm doing okay.
That's good. Where are you from originally?
I'm from Greenwich, Connecticut.
Really?
Yes.
When did you move to LA?
I moved here in 2008, so about five years ago.
How often do you go back to your hometown?
I try to go back at least once a year. Sometimes I go more, sometimes less.
How does it compare to LA?
Overall, I think I like where I'm from better than LA in general.
Why?
I think that other than it being somewhere I'm familiar with, the type of people that are there are just more my type and what I'm used to and less superficial.
I understand. Why did you move to LA?
I moved out here for college after I graduated high school and my mom and sister live in California.
How easy was it for you to get used to living in LA?
Initially, it was easy because I felt like it was a new experience, so you kind of adapt and just are experiencing everything at once. But then after the first few years when it really sets in how different it is and what life is out here, it became more difficult than originally.
What's your study at school?
Fine Arts and Photography.
That sounds interesting. How did you decide to do that?
I was interested in photography since high school. I did a lot of programs and got awards and things like that and publishments. So I decided to pursue art.
Are you still working on that?
Yes, I have a fine arts degree that I got last year.
Awesome. Are you happy to do that?
Yeah, I really enjoy working or interning in forensics. I like that better than initially what I wanted to do was freelance photography. I feel like it's a more secure job and it's very interesting.
What's one of your most memorable experiences?
That's an interesting question. I guess just my childhood in general, growing up.
Can you tell me about that?
Well, my family is very close, my extended family as well, and most of them live within the area or on the east coast in general. So we would always do large family parties and things for holidays and religious purposes and things like that.
That sounds like a great situation.
Yeah, it is really fun and we try and all get together as much as possible, which is more difficult now since everyone is spread out amongst different states and countries.
Do you consider yourself more shy or outgoing?
I consider myself more shy. Sometimes when I'm feeling tense, I turn on the fish tank screensaver. Hey, I know it's not Hawaii, but it's the best I've got.
What do you do to relax?
I watch reality television. I think it's kind of funny and lighthearted.
Like what?
I watch like Bravo TV, like the Real Housewives shows, and just like funny things that you don't really need to pay attention to.
Okay. How are you at controlling your temper?
I'm good, I guess. I don't really have like a temper. If I'm more stressed out, it definitely shows in my attitude, but I don't really have like anger.
When was the last time you argued with someone and what was it about?
When me and my boyfriend bicker all the time just like about like insignificant things. But other than that, I had an argument with my dad a few days ago.
Can you tell me about that?
There's been like some tension going on since I went and visited over the holidays this past winter, things about his girlfriend and he thinks that I should be the one to make some kind of effort to have a relationship with her, although he doesn't for whatever reason think that it should go both ways. So for like the 30th time, we were on the phone and he was telling me how I need to call her and speak to her and I had told him that I was going to do it over this past weekend because of the Jewish holidays and he kind of was just like very immature and telling me, oh, forget it, she doesn't want to hear from you now and kind of just like I could care less because I don't care about having a relationship with her. So she doesn't want to hear from me, you know, it's easier for me.
Yeah, that sucks. Tell me about a situation that you wish you would handle differently.
I mean, it's been the same recurring argument a lot and I wish that I could, sometimes I do, but I wish that the times that it turns into an explosive fight that I could just bite my tongue. But the thing is, is that he says certain things that are untrue or things he knows that like will take me off that are really nasty and that he shouldn't be saying to me. So I kind of just like lose it and I can't really like not say anything.
Tell me about the hardest decision you've ever had to make.
Well, I guess the hardest decision I made, which I didn't only realize that it's the hardest decision, like looking back is once you decide where to after you graduate high school where to go to college, because for me, I basically changed my entire life and moved away and did all that on my own. So it didn't seem like that hard of a decision at the time. It felt like just like a progression of the next step. But looking back now, that's probably one of the hardest decisions I made.
OK. Tell me about an event or something that you wish you could erase from your memory.
Well, I wish I could erase the event or seeing my grandmother's funeral, which obviously it wouldn't change anything. But it wasn't seeing her there was not something I'd want to like have in my memory.
There's someone that's been a positive influence on you.
She was. She was a very positive influence and always was not judgmental. And now, I mean, my parents are great role models just in general. I mean, they're very successful people. So whether or not we have like disagreements or that we're separate people, they kind of are good role models in terms of what you want to have when you are older.
How easy is it for you to get a good night's sleep?
Usually it's easy. The problem is staying asleep no matter how late I go to bed, whether it's 10 p.m. or 4 a.m. I will be up like clockwork by 730 or 8 o'clock in the morning, the latest every single day. And I can't seem to figure out why I cannot stay asleep longer.
Are you triggered by something?
No, I just in the morning, I guess I'm a lighter sleeper, but I just wake up like I just cannot stay asleep anymore, which never used to be a problem this consistent. But now it's I cannot remember the last time I slept past 830 in the morning.
What are you like when you don't sleep well?
I mean, it just makes if I have to do stuff during the day, it makes it a lot more tiring. But it doesn't really. I'm so used to it now. It doesn't really change my mood. It's just part of every day.
OK. How have you been feeling lately?
Um, I don't know. I kind of just feel very like so so just no extreme highs, no extreme lows. It's kind of one note land. I mean, nothing like lately. Um, like recently, it's just I would say over a period of years, I've kind of progressively become more seclusive and just reserved and not very outgoing.
No, I have been diagnosed with anxiety. I had some breathing problems for a day or two and I had to go to the hospital because I thought it was more serious because I couldn't breathe. But they said that it was a little bit more serious. So I had to go to the hospital. I think in the right setting and with the person who's doing it, if they're open minded and the therapist is helpful and good at what they're doing. Then, yeah, no, I haven't been to therapy since I was a kid. I went because my parents thought it would be a good idea to like deal with whatever issues they were having with me. But it was never so I mean, we just sat around and talked about my day. It wasn't I didn't feel like I needed therapy at the time. So I didn't really get much out of it.
Well, I was happy when I was back home at my boyfriend's house with his family over the New Year's holiday. When I'm there, I can always just we save up our money. So it's a complete vacation. I don't have to worry about paying bills. I don't have to worry about what I have to do tomorrow, who I have to deal with. I just every morning we wake up, we just go to the doctor. I don't have to worry about paying bills. I don't have to worry about what I have to do tomorrow, who I have to deal with. So we wake up, we hang out, just enjoy the day.
That's great. Is there anything you regret?
In general?
Yeah. I regret the college I chose to go to. I didn't be from the East Coast. The whole collegiate system is set up a lot differently. The universities out there are not the same as the tight-knit California school system out here. So when I was researching colleges, I kind of thought that Santa Monica College was just a general college, just like Boston College back home or any other school with the name college at the end of it. I didn't realize until the end of my first year even that it was more like a transfer school. I didn't even realize you couldn't get a bachelor's degree from there when I went. So it kind of created more problems for me.
What advice would you give yourself 10 or 20 years ago?
Well, considering I'm 22, I'd probably say 10 years ago, I would give myself the advice to probably stay closer to home and to have really pursued other options rather than just be completely invested in moving to California.
How would your best friend describe you?
My best friend would describe me as a great, charismatic, funny, outgoing, socially enjoyable person, which is different than how people who aren't my good friends would describe me, which I mean, I don't, I mean, it is what it is. I am very outgoing and have a great time when I'm with my friends in my element. But around strangers and in like uncomfortable groups and things, I just, I am very shy and don't really speak much.
Tell me about something you did recently that you really enjoyed.
Recently, my friend was visiting and we went to a Clippers basketball game a few weeks ago, and I really enjoyed that.
Nice. Yeah. What would you say are some of your best qualities?
Um, I'm very caring. I am a very good judge of character, which I mean, I guess, I mean, I consider it to be a quality for myself. I'm very, I mean, not very affectionate. I'm more, I mean, I guess, I guess so.
Okay. I think I've asked everything I need to. Thanks for sharing your thoughts with me. Goodbye.
Thanks. I can chat with you a little bit more about.
summary:
Okay, here is a summary of the interviewee's experiences with depression, written from the first-person perspective:

Lately, I've been feeling very "so-so" – no extreme highs or lows, just kind of one-note. Over the past few years, I’ve become more secluded and reserved. I was diagnosed with anxiety after experiencing some breathing problems and going to the hospital. While I believe therapy can be helpful in the right setting, my childhood experiences with it weren't beneficial. One of the happiest times I can remember recently was when I was at my boyfriend's house with his family over the New Year's holiday because I didn't have to worry about responsibilities. I also have trouble sleeping, waking up early no matter when I go to bed, but I'm used to it now and it doesn't really change my mood.

transcript:
Okay. Thank you. Hi, I'm Ellie. Thanks for coming in today. I was created to talk to people in a safe and secure environment. I'm not a therapist, but I'm here to learn about people and would love to learn about you. I'll ask a few questions to get us started. And please feel free to tell me everything. Your answers are totally confidential. Are you okay with this? So, how are you doing today?
That's good.
Where are you from originally?
Really?
What are some things you really like about LA?
What are some things you don't really like about LA?
Do you travel a lot?
I do. I go to school in Chicago. And I've been to New York a couple times. San Francisco. And I took a road trip across the country. That was cool. I saw a couple states.
What do you enjoy about traveling?
Seeing new places. Going to landmarks that I've only read about or seen pictures of.
I'd love to hear about one of your trips.
I traveled from Los Angeles to Chicago taking Route 66. And the best part was seeing the Grand Canyon for the first time. It was the coolest thing I've ever seen, probably.
Awesome. How did you feel in that moment?
Happy. And then just happy. It was beautiful. It was nice. I haven't felt like that in a long time.
What's your dream job?
I love making movies. But part of me really loves making people laugh and being in front of the camera. So a comedian, a comedic actor would be totally great. But that's hard.
Do you consider yourself more shy or outgoing?
I am super outgoing. And I love talking to people a lot. I like being the center of attention. Sometimes when I'm feeling tense, I turn on the fish tank screen saver. Hey, I know it's not Hawaii, but it's the best I've got.
What do you do to relax?
I like to watch mindless television. Like Toddlers and Tiaras and Duck Dynasty. I like to watch TV programs where I don't have to pay attention at all.
How are you at controlling your temper?
I'm okay at it. I get really emotional really fast. But I'm usually able to keep my anger down and not lash out at others and stuff, for the most part.
Has that gotten you in trouble?
Sometimes I get into arguments and fights with my friends and people who are important to me really easily. And I hate apologizing to people, so the fights could last pretty long.
When was the last time you argued with someone and what was it about?
My best friend Ryan, I think. And it was about our relationship and just how we kind of messed it up and crossed some lines and how we were going to go back to the way it was before.
How hard is that?
Really hard. He's my best friend and I miss him. But we messed up and it's just not the same. It's like not the same friendship.
I'm sorry.
Me too.
Tell me about a situation that you wish you would handle differently.
Too many. I guess... When I have a boyfriend and he's a girlfriend, which was not okay, I wish I would have just realized that this was bad and just would have stopped there and not have let it continue for weeks, which led to my breakup and then our friendship being really messed up.
Could you have done anything to avoid it?
I guess not spend as much time with him as I did. Being more assertive.
Tell me about the hardest decision you've ever had to make.
I guess... It was in November. I was very depressed and suicidal. So I told my friend what I was feeling and that she needed to take me to the ER. And from the ER I had the choice to, I don't know, I guess go home or get sent to a mental hospital. And even though I felt like I didn't have a choice, I knew it was my choice and I decided to go to the mental hospital, which was like the worst experience of my life ever.
Can you tell me about that?
Um, it was awful. It was in Chicago and it was scary. I didn't know anyone and they just like take all your stuff and they put you in some scrubs and they just start giving you medication and you're basically left to your own devices. There were only like three group therapy sessions a day and everyone there was mostly men and they were all really old. And it was scary. I didn't know anyone, everyone. Most of the people there weren't depressed, they were violent. So that was pretty scary and I just, it was really hard for me.
What made you decide to do that?
I had been so depressed for like a month. I stopped going to my classes and work and I told my teachers lies about being sick and I just kept calling in sick to work. I dropped a class and I was failing my classes and not turning in any work and I wasn't talking to any of my friends and I was drinking a lot and passing out and vomiting everywhere and I was just in a really bad place. And when I finally was going to kill myself, I realized I needed help. It was. I had severe depression when I was a younger teenager and I tried to kill myself then and I got put in therapy for quite some time. So I figured I don't want to go down that bad path again. I just want to get better. So I had to do it. I had to get help.
Do you feel like therapy is useful?
I feel like if you have the right therapist, it's really useful. I had one therapist that I really liked and I thought we could have gone really far, but sadly she's back in Chicago and I'm in Los Angeles. So I have to make do with this new therapist. She's okay. We're not that great together, but she's who I have right now. It's better than nothing.
Why?
Ever since I got out of the hospital and I began medication for my depression, I just haven't been able to sleep well. Falling asleep is hard. Staying asleep is hard. Have really crazy, vivid dreams that wake me up and are disturbing. I guess just sometimes they reflect things that I'm worried about or happening in my life, but they're just they're scary and they seem so real that sometimes I wake up and I have to ask my mom, like, did we go here? Did we do this? Did this really happen? And it's usually, no, you dream that. Sometimes I've gotten so scared. I like talk in my sleep and wake myself up. Probably like two nights ago.
Tell me how you spend your ideal weekend.
I guess my ideal weekend would be sleeping in and then catching a movie with my friends. Maybe going home with them and bake some cookies, eat all the cookies, watch some TV, have a sleepover and then like make pancakes in the morning and watch more movies. We watch a lot of movies.
I would like to do my free time.
Go for a walk. I don't know. Go to the beach.
It was nice to meet you. Bye.
summary: Okay, so I've struggled with depression, especially recently. Last November, I was in a really bad place – skipping classes, failing school, isolating myself from friends, and drinking heavily. I was even suicidal. It got to the point where I knew I needed help and told a friend I needed to go to the ER. I chose to go to a mental hospital in Chicago, which was honestly the worst experience of my life. It was scary and isolating. I started medication after I got out, but now I have trouble sleeping and have really disturbing dreams. I had severe depression as a younger teenager and tried to kill myself then and got put in therapy for quite some time. I do think therapy can be helpful if you find the right therapist. I had one I really connected with, but she's back in Chicago. My current therapist is okay, but it's better than nothing.

If things go right, how about that?

summary: In 2004, I was diagnosed with depression. My life had become so stressful that I felt like I had to do something, or things would end badly. I currently attend therapy, and I find it useful as a sounding board. I feel that therapy, along with medication, has been helpful. Since starting therapy, I've noticed changes in myself. When I don’t sleep well, I become irritable and tired.

All right. Great. Thank you. Hi, I'm Ellie. I'm not a therapist, but I'm here to learn about people and I'd love to learn about you. I'll ask a few questions to get us started. And please feel free to tell me anything. Your answers are fully confidential. Are you okay with this?

Never.

Completely different. I am not a perfect parent, but I love my son. I take care of him. He's the first priority in my life, and they weren't like that at all. Tell me about your relationship with your family.
Well, my parents are dead. I didn't speak to my dad at all before he died. I have a sister and a brother that actually, I don't know where they are. I don't speak to them either.

Probably more shy because I consider myself more reserved. Sometimes when I'm feeling tense, I turn on the fish tank screensaver. Hey, I know it's not Hawaii. It's the best I've got. What do you do to relax?
I like to listen to music.

I listen to all sorts of music, but my favorite when I'm relaxing is 80s music. Cheesy, cheesy, but true. How are you at controlling your temper?

Because he was cheating on me. Tell me about an event or something that you wish you could erase from your memory.
Um, that would have to be, well, I don't know. I mean, I don't know if I'd want to erase anything from my memory because it makes me who I am today. So I can't really think of one event that I would want to erase.
I see what you mean. How easy is it for you to get a good night's sleep?
I don't get a good night's sleep. It's not easy. I wake up a lot in the night.
Why?
I don't know. I wish I knew. If I knew, I could change it. I could try to do something about it, but I just don't, I don't know. What are you like when you don't sleep well?
Um, grumpy, irritable. How have you been feeling lately?

Yes.

Ten years ago after my son was born.

No.

It was probably this morning I was playing with my son.
How did you feel in that moment?
Just really happy. I wasn't thinking about any of the other crap in my life. I could just forget it. So I was feeling really, really happy. How would your best friend describe you?

I think I would spend my ideal weekend in a sunny place like Palm Springs with my son, hanging around the pool, having fun, going out to dinner. Is there someone that's been a positive influence in your life?
Two of my friends, two really good girlfriends, I think have been really positive influences in my life. Can you tell me about that?
Her life is worse than mine, but we can always commiserate together. She's just really positive. She's always happy, always up, always looking to the bright side. That's so good to hear. What are you most proud of in your life? Tell me about something you did recently that you really enjoyed.
I went over to a friend's house and we had movie night. We watched a grown-up movie and had dinner and wine. The boys were in another room watching movies and playing video games. It was just a relaxed, fun evening. That sounds like a great situation. Okay, I think I've asked everything I need to. Thanks for sharing your thoughts with me.
Sure. Bye.
summary:
Okay, here's my story regarding my experiences with depression:

I was diagnosed with depression about ten years ago, a year after my son was born. I sought help because I felt like I couldn't cope with life; I was so down and felt incapable of doing anything. I don't go to talk therapy anymore because I haven't found it helpful. Some therapists just sit there silently, and others give advice that I don't find useful. I am on medication management though. Lately, I've been feeling grumpy, irritable, down, and angry, mainly because of everything I'm going through with my soon-to-be ex-husband. I wish I wasn't sad, and I wish I was more confident. I also don’t sleep well and wake up a lot during the night, which makes me even grumpier.

Okay. Here's the cleaned transcript:

Hi, I'm Ellie. Thanks for coming in today. I'm just creative to talk to people and think into their environment. Gang violence.
Hi, Mr. I'm sure you can tell by my shoes. I'm not much of a world explorer. Do you travel a lot?
No, not really. I've traveled one time to Arizona and one time to Stockton, California, and another time to Barstow, California, but I don't do much traveling right now, mainly because of finances.
What did you study at school?
I studied alcohol and drug counseling.
