I just felt it in my heart that that's what I was supposed to be doing with my life is helping people overcome their addictions. That was a kind of easy choice. I got some advice from people and I just went into it to do it just to see what it was. I finished school and did an internship and got hired. I believe that's what I'm supposed to be doing with my life.
Are you still working on that?
I'm not working right now. I actually moved away and I was married and we had to move away. We moved away because renting was cheaper, so I actually had to give up that job in order to make that move. Since I came back down, I've been filling out applications and sending resumes and trying to get interviews so I can get back into counseling.
How hard is that?
It can be very difficult at times because I have a felony. I can't work with the youth and I can't work with the elderly, but the regular adults, I can. Then you have to be certified and I'm not certified yet. You have to work a certain amount of hours in order to be certified. Before they even allow you to take the test, you have to work a certain amount of hours. Right now I'm just trying to get into interns, try to intern and show people what I can do as a counselor because everything about me is not seen on my resume. They just want people to be certified. Not being certified, the experience and the fact that I have a felony makes it hard.
What's your dream job?
My dream job is to open my own facility or as an author.
Do you consider yourself a shy or a felon?
That depends on people. I mainly adapt my personality to the people that I'm around. If people are perky, then I'm going to be perky. If they're standoffish, then I may seem shy, but I'm not shy. I'm just giving them their space and allowing them to decide when they want to open up. If people open up right away, then I open up right away. Sometimes when I'm feeling tense, I turn on the fish tape screen saver. Hey, I know it's not Hawaii, but it's a trusted guy.
What do you do to relax?
I mainly listen to music or I watch YouTube, write poetry, or just close my eyes and just lay down and pretend like I can sing, which I can't. Another thing I do is I eat ice cream.
Tell me about controlling your temper.
Controlling my temper, I'm very, very good at it. It depends on what it is. I have to say that the last time I lost my temper was because I felt like somebody was scaring my mother. I lost my temper, but 99 times out of 100, I don't lose my temper. I don't like to raise my voice. I just like to be calm and cool. I like everybody to be comfortable. I don't want anybody to be frightened or anything. There's no reason for anybody to be frightened and for us to be angry and taking out our past frustrations out on people who had nothing to do with it. I just believe that, and I believe angry outbursts to be a link to heart problems and high blood pressure. I definitely don't want that.
Tell me about a situation that you were seeing in a different way.
Well, I was just telling you about, it was my mother's husband. To tell you the truth, I could have handled that differently, but when I seen the look in my mama's eyes of fear, I just lost it. I snapped. I told my mother, I don't like this. You need to take care of this because I don't know how long I can keep my composure as far as this. I've been seeing this guy mistreat my mother, but that's her husband. I kept my distance in their relationship, but when I saw her having fear in her eyes, that triggered a part of me that I don't like very much because I know if I get angry, I usually stay angry for a long time. So I should have just left. I should have just left and went home and rested and got up in the next morning and went to church. But yeah, we had a big time explosion and that created a lot of damage for about six to nine months. So yeah, those six to nine months, I can't get back. That's very hard.
Yes. Tell me about your relationship with your family.
Well, my brother's in prison. I haven't seen him in 20 years. He's been there 20 years. My sister moved to Chicago 13 years ago. I haven't seen her since then. So I'm only close to my mother. And my son, I haven't seen him in five years and I'm still looking for him and waiting for the day I see him again and how that's going to turn out for me. I just, you know, I have a small family and I have family in Chicago, but I don't mess around with that side of the family just because of what I've seen and heard. So I just don't want it to happen to me at all. So I just keep my distance.
Is there someone who's been a positive influence in your life?
Someone who's been a positive influence in my life, I would say... Taught me how to get my temper under control and how to express my emotions without me expressing my emotions, being threatening to someone else. And taught me how to like monitor my emotions and monitor my thoughts and how strong my thoughts are. And when they're really strong, that's when I just need to be quiet until that intense fizzling subsides and then I can speak rationally and not just emotionally. And of course, he's he was the one that told me that I should look into being a drug and alcohol counselor. My father, he's got 27 years clean and sober right now. He used to live on Skid Row and the way he changed his life around and, you know, the way he approached me as a father was just something that I'll never forget.
What's something you feel guilty about?
Feel guilty about? My grandfather. He passed away in 2004 and at that time I was just getting out of prison. 2002 I was just getting out of prison and he came to see me and he told me in so many words that he wasn't going to be around for that much longer. But I didn't get it because I had a lot of drugs and alcohol in my life at the time and my life was crowded with things that I considered to be more important than that. Plus the fact I didn't understand him, what he was saying. But when he died, I figured out that he was telling me that I should probably spend more time with him before it's time for him to go. But I couldn't see it then. And I feel I think about it all the time.
Okay. Tell me about home or something that you wish you could erase from your memory.
Something I could erase from my memory? What made a day my brother hit my mom? I always replay that over and over in my mind. And it's like that's one memory I can just go without replaying my mind over and over again. So yeah, that memory right there.
How did you feel about that memory?
I felt conflicting feelings. Because on one hand, my brother was protecting me from getting beat. And on the other hand, he was hitting my mom. So it's kind of in the middle.
How easy is it for you to get a good night's sleep?
Most nights I don't. I go to sleep maybe three in the morning. And I'm probably I'm more than likely up at seven in the morning. So I don't get much sleep. It depends on the environment I'm in. If I don't sleep well. I'm going eventually I'm going to be irritable, but it doesn't happen right away. It depends on my environment and who's around me. And it's just a matter of time before my book is out there and people know about me because I've had a lot of time to study human behavior and things like that. And I have a lot to offer humanity. So it's just a matter of time before that the public is exposed to what I've been gathering.

And the acquisition of a sense of humor was a major, major breakthrough for me. So I know my thoughts have changed. And with my thoughts changing, my behavior has changed. I still have to monitor it. My thoughts and my behavior, I still have to monitor them. But overall, back then I just tolerated myself. Now I actually like myself. And it will behoo you to feel the same way.
Okay. Have you ever been diagnosed with dysplasia?
No.

No.

Awesome. How do your best friends describe you?
My best friend would describe me, he calls me the truth.

Because I always tell the truth and people try to hide stuff and I always reveal it. They can't hide it from me. I have a statement that says I see through you like a clear glass with nothing in it. Like I said, like a clear glass with nothing in it. And yes, that's why he calls me the truth.
What are some things you wish you could change about yourself?
I wish I would have never, well, obviously I wish I would have never went to prison. I wish that I could change, well, my economic status, my employment status, and my teeth. That's like a problem area for me. I did a lot of stupid things years ago and they caught up with me and I didn't take care of my teeth. And now that I need to be confident about myself as I can be, it always comes up every now and then, the thought, like, I wonder if they're looking at my teeth. I wonder if they're looking at my teeth. I never get the impression that they are, but in the back of my mind there's these thoughts that says, are they looking at my teeth? So I would really change that. And I would change my physical size. I think I would like to be at least 35 pounds heavier, but I'm working on it. 20 years ago, which would make me 18, I would have, at that time I was a big time high school basketball player for Freedman High School and I had colleges coming to see me and I would have given myself the opportunity to stay away from the troublemakers because I didn't and I blew my opportunity to play college basketball for Duke Blue Devils and who knows, I could have been playing for the Lakers last night. But, hey.
I'm most proud of what?
I'm most proud of my mom. Really. She graduated from school. She had a full-time job. She would wake up at 5 in the morning, go to work, get off her job at 3.30, go straight to the college, leave the college at 9 o'clock at night. She does this five days a week and still had the strength to maintain. She was on the Dean's List and the President's List, so doing all of this, you know, when they say that older people can't do things, I just think that dispels that rumor. And she recently got her license as an evangelist in the church, so I'm just real proud of that. Her life has been affecting people in a positive way. So, yeah, my mom.
Okay, thank you. Goodbye. Okay, thank you.

This lack of sleep can make me irritable, especially if I'm in a difficult environment. I also have a memory of my brother hitting my mom that replays in my mind often, and it brings up conflicting feelings. I wish I could erase it.

It just takes you there. So just I kept raising my voice said some things I shouldn't have and just was more so allowed myself to lose control of the contact. I like to really feel in control of the contact and so it just took me there. My blood pressure was raised. Excuse me. And that was just a kind of a mess for a while for like maybe 30 minutes or an hour after that. Just irritable and agitated and upset. And so I always try to you know go back and pull from those and you know do my own sense of feedback and see how I could you know handle things differently. But that's one I definitely wish I could have kept my cool and been more level headed and not really raise my voice and you know been more polite.
Okay. Tell me about the hardest decision you've ever had to make.
Hmm. Well I probably have had a couple but probably the most is a situation years ago when I just had my sons and they probably my twins they were probably about two and I was in a situation with their father again and became pregnant and it just was not a good time. And he pretty much you know was not comfortable with me having another child at the time. And I wasn't comfortable with having another child either but wanted to keep the baby. But he put me under so much stress and you know kind of I want to say really pushed me into having terminating the pregnancy. And that's always stayed with me and I've always missed that pregnancy that child I think about that that baby or what could have been. I try not to hold any anger or resentment towards him or anybody about it. But I know deep down I secretly if I had it to do all over again I would have just I would have kept the baby and move forward. So that would have been probably the hardest especially emotionally. I could deal with a lot and I have dealt with a lot you know being unemployed or you know a lot of financial problems. But that to me was the hardest.
Thank you.
No. No.
How have you been feeling lately?
Okay you know I was laid off in December so I've been constantly trying to do things to you know get back on my feet. So that's been a little tough. I've had to face a lot of challenges and dealing with that and issues with child support and trying to find another job and going back to school. So my range of emotions have just have been just that a range and a very good friend of mine now who we both started off you know in the same place about five years ago. Well she's been able to move forward and going with her life and now she's graduating in next month from USC with her master's in social work. So I'm feeling a little envious of that and I have been for like the past year but more so recently although I'm very very happy for her you know and she's a good person and she deserves it. But you know of course you've done a lot of what she was me so that too has kind of been bothering me. Hi Ms. Lola.
What would you say are some of your best qualities?
Well I'm really good with people. I communicate well. I like to talk. I'm really good with children. That's why I would like to teach or be a counselor. Although I have not really tapped into it I know I'm a very creative person. I know I write pretty good. I could possibly be a creative writer but I know I'm very creative. So if given the opportunity I know I could tap into that and really develop those skills. Something like with maybe songwriting, fiction writing, probably like interior decorating. Anything artistic. Just anything because I love music. I love the arts. I love drama. I love plays. I'm not a big fashion buff but I do love fashion and makeup and stuff like that. So I think those are my strong points as well as just getting along with people. I know I will make a great counselor. My friends come to me all the time. I have a good ear for listening. I'm a great mediator and I know how to because I've been through a lot. One of my friends called me the voice of reason. The one that's actually graduating from SC. I know I'm light years ahead of a lot of people when it comes to insight and wisdom. I don't know if it has to do with having older parents myself or how I grew up. I had very traditional southern parents who instilled a lot of great values in me. Or if it has anything to do with my astrological sign, I'm a Pisces. I'm really good with people. Just period. Like I said, I have my moments but I know if it's something I could go into and develop, I would do well.
Is there anything you regret?
Not really. Some of the situations. I wish I would have waited to maybe have gotten married before I had children. Picked a different partner. I say that because my son's father is great. A great father for my kids but not so much as a partner for me. We're not together. I'm just saying overall. I think I would say, if I could let me backtrack that, not finishing school when I should have. Not following my dreams and goals and doing things as I was planning initially. I think that would be the one thing I could say I regret. Not following my goals and finishing school on time and pursuing what I really wanted to do.
What advice would you give yourself 10 or 20 years ago?
Stay focused and finish school. Pick a career path and stay on that. Stay motivated and don't let anything or anybody deter you.
What are you most proud of in your life?
I think I'm pretty stable and consistent. Overall, how I face adversity. How I face things. I'm a pretty committed person. If I say I'm going to do something, I try to stick to it. I'm a very loyal friend. I've done a pretty good job with raising my kids.
So long. Great. Thank you. Bye bye.
summary: Looking back, there have been periods where I really struggled. After being laid off, facing child support issues, and trying to juggle school and job hunting, my emotions were all over the place. I felt envious of a friend who was graduating with her Master's, knowing I wanted to be where she was. The hardest decision I ever made was years ago, when I was pressured into terminating a pregnancy. That has always stayed with me, and I still think about that child. While I've faced a lot of challenges, that remains the most emotionally difficult thing I've gone through.

transcript:
Okay, thank you. Hi, I'm Ellie. Thanks for coming in today. I was created to talk to people in a safe and secure environment. I'm not a therapist, but I'm here to learn about people and I'd love to learn about you. I'll ask a few questions to get it started. And please feel free to tell me anything. Your answers are totally confidential. Are you okay with this? Okay. So, how are you doing today?
I'm wonderful. How are you?
I'm great. Thanks. Where are you from originally?
California.
Really?
Yes.
What are some things you really like about LA?
The weather is one of them. The food and the way everything is centrally located.
What are some things you don't really like about LA?
The traffic, the smog, and it's just gotten really overcrowded.
I see what you mean. I'm sure you can tell by my shoes. I'm not much of a world explorer. Do you travel a lot?
I wouldn't say a lot, but I do try to travel at least once or twice every two years.
What do you enjoy about traveling?
Just exploring different things and being able to have different experiences, things of that nature, and learning new things and just different cultures. I like to learn about different cultures, and when you travel, you get a sense of feedback from different cultures and different areas. So I like that. I'd love to hear about your trips.
I just came from Miami last year. I went to Miami for a week and a half. It was really nice. The weather was great. It was my first time going. The weather was wonderful. The people were really nice. It was really a great experience. I went out there for a particular event. They have something every year where everyone comes out from all over. You just kind of party and hang out and meet new people. It was really fun.
What's one of your most memorable experiences?
From that trip, I would say swimming in the beautiful Miami beach waters. It was wonderful.
That sounds like a great situation.
Yeah, it was.
What did you study at school?
Child development.
That sounds interesting. How did you decide to do that?
Well, I've always been interested in children since I was younger. I babysat a lot, so I had a lot of experience with kids at a young age. As I grew older, I realized that it was something that I liked to do. That's when I looked into child development courses. I thought that it was something that I would enjoy doing. I started taking classes, and the rest is history.
Are you still working on that?
I am, yes. It's been 15 years in August.
Wow. What's your dream job?
My dream job? I would say to become a principal.
Why?
Well, it's something that I've thought about doing for a while now. I've actually just began the steps to try to get that going. I'm going to be back in school, and I'm going to be taking courses so that I can make that happen, because it is a dream of mine.
Thank you. How hard is that?
It's going to be pretty difficult. There is several years of schooling that I have ahead of me. It's definitely going to be a challenge, but it's something that I'm up for because it is a dream job of mine. It's something that I'm willing to do.
I understand. Do you consider yourself more shy or outgoing?
A little bit of both, I think. I can be shy at times, and outgoing as well.
Okay. Sometimes when I'm feeling tense, I turn on the fish tank screensaver. Hey, I know it's not Hawaii, but it's the best I've got. What do you do to relax?
I meditate. I'm a big meditator, so I love meditating. I love reading and having a nice, quiet, peaceful time.
How are you at controlling your temper?
Oh, wow. I'm very good at that. Again, a series of meditations that I do, it involves deep breathing and just really centering yourself to where you can feel your heartbeat, and you can really feel everything in your body.
That's good. When was the last time you argued with someone, and what was it about?
It's about just the way he responds sometimes to me. It can be a little aggressive. We're just trying to work with that because I don't respond well to aggression. I totally tune out, and that's actually what happened. Yeah, that was it.
How did you feel in that moment?
I felt very frustrated, and I actually felt angered too, but more frustrated. I felt saddened too because I don't like arguing, so it was a little bit of all those emotions at one time.
Tell me about a situation that you wish you would handle differently.
A situation which I wish I would have handled differently. Honestly, I haven't had a situation like that in years. I've pretty much mastered my responses to certain stimuli. I've got that down.
Tell me about the hardest decision you've ever had to make.
The hardest decision I've ever had to make? Well, it was when I was 16 years old, and I became a teenage mother. I was pregnant at 16, and I had a lot of pressure from family to give my child up for adoption or to abort. I chose life, so that was one of the hardest decisions, if not the hardest decisions, to make as a 16-year-old teenager. Whether I wanted to continue to be a kid and a teenager, or whether I wanted to embark on raising a life when I was just a child myself. That, I think, was the hardest decision I had to make.
How do you cope with them?
Well, my son is almost 19 now, so it's 19 years later. I actually am so glad it was one of the best things that I ever did by not choosing to abort him. Being pro-life, pro-choice, pro-life. I have not regretted the decision. That's my only child, and I love him. He is just a blessing, and I feel very special to be his mom.
Do you find it easy to be a parent?
No, it's not easy. It definitely has its difficulties, just as anything.
What are some ways that you're different as a parent than your parents?
The first way is I actually listen to my son, and I accept his feedback, even if I don't like it. I allow him to express himself. Unfortunately, when I was little, there was not a lot of conversation from parent to child. It was more like we were just told what to do, and we did it. With my son, I give him options. I allow him to express himself. I allow him to give me feedback, negative or positive. I feel that it's really important for a child to develop their voice at a young age. As parents, you have to be supportive in that and make sure that you nurture that, because that's the way that they develop.
How easy is it for you to get a good night's sleep?
It depends. It really depends. It depends on the time that I go to sleep. It depends on the time that I woke up. There are a lot of factors. I can't just give you one answer. I would say that it varies. Sometimes I can go to sleep and fall asleep right away, and other times I can go to sleep and it might take a while to actually fall asleep. It varies.
How have you been feeling lately?
I've been feeling great lately. I really have been. I can't say that the last week didn't affect me, the argument with my husband. Other than that, I've been feeling really good.
Have you ever been diagnosed with PTSD?
No, I haven't.
Have you been diagnosed with depression?
No, I have not.
Tell me about the last time you felt really happy.
You know what? Honestly, I feel happy every day. Every day I wake up, I'm happy because that is a chance for me to take advantage. Carpe diem sees the day. I feel blessed. Every morning I wake up, it's a blessing because I realize that some people did not wake up. Some people are homeless. Some people are going through so many situations that are really disheartening. That's not me. I feel really, really blessed every day.
That's great. Thank you. How are your best friends around you?
As nurturing, patient, loving, friendly, kind of reserved.
What are some things you wish you could change about yourself?
Well, I wish that I had already completed college and had my master's degree. Sometimes I wish I was a little bit more knowledgeable in certain subjects. If I could change anything, I would change that, those two things. Also, I would be a little bit more outgoing and less of an introvert.
Is there anything you regret?
You know what? No regrets. You live and learn. Nothing is perfect. Everything that I've gone through has made me the person that I am today. So I wouldn't change anything because I'm happy with the person that I am today.
What advice would you give yourself 10 or 20 years ago?
Oh man, to stay in school. To stay in school and to get your education and to put that first and foremost before a relationship, even before your career, I really, really would have told myself to stay focused and to get a great education.
What are you most proud of in your life?
I'm most proud of where I've come from as a teenage mother. Being a statistic and actually changing that. Being on my same job for 15 years now, I'm really proud of that. I've been married for 13 years. I'm really proud of that. Happily married to my best friend and my soulmate. Nothing's perfect, but he's my best friend and I love him. I'm also proud of my son being the mother that I am and the son that I've raised. I'm proud of the job that I've done. I really applaud myself for that.
Okay, I think I've asked everything I need to. Thanks for sharing your thoughts with me.
You're welcome. You were wonderful. Thank you. Bye-bye.
summary: I haven't been diagnosed with depression. There was a week recently where an argument with my husband affected me, but generally, I feel happy every day. I wake up feeling blessed and grateful for the opportunities I have.

summary:
Okay, here's my story about dealing with depression:

I think I've been dealing with depression, or at least intense sadness, for a long time, maybe 30 or 35 years. It's not a formal diagnosis, but I know the feeling well. I initially sought help because I wanted to improve my life, be the best version of myself, and ultimately, be happy. I've been in therapy on and off, but honestly, I'm not sure how much it's helped. I haven't noticed significant changes that I can directly attribute to therapy, and it's hard to separate its impact from just the passage of time.

Lately, I've been feeling particularly anxious, stressed, and sad. I'm currently unemployed, which is putting a lot of pressure on me, and it feels like things just aren't going my way. I have trouble sleeping; I can't fall asleep easily and wake up often. I’m very hard on myself and beat myself up about things every day. For example, I procrastinated on getting my car smogged, and now it's going to cost me a lot of money to fix. I also regret not keeping my last job. I wish I could be more content and happier, and give myself a break more often. The last time I felt truly happy was at my son's wedding last month. Seeing him happy, successful, and a better person than me made me really proud.

transcript:
Okay. Thank you. Hi, I'm Ellie. Thanks for coming in today. I'm not a therapist, but I'm here to learn about people and would love to learn about you. I'll ask a few questions to get started. And please feel free to tell me anything. Your answers are totally confidential. Are you okay with this?

Los Angeles.

Sports, outdoor sports mainly.
Like what?
Surfing, snowboarding, mountain biking, rock climbing.
Awesome. What are some things you don't really like about LA?
Traffic.
I see what you mean. I'm sure you can tell by my shoes. I'm not much of a world explorer. Do you travel a lot?
Yes.

Experiencing different cultures.

Well, I love going to Mexico. And it's so much different from California and Western culture, so to speak. I know Mexico is a Western civilization, but the level of entertainment and the level of education is so much different that they're like two different worlds.
What's one of your most memorable experiences?
Traveling, you mean?
Yeah.
I would have to say going to an island off the coast of Fiji. Fiji, the name is Tabaruwa, and it's a very small island. You can walk around it in 30 or 40 minutes. And it's a place where you go to go surfing. And it is an incredible, visually incredible and experientially incredible place.
Nice. What did you study at school?
I studied biology.
How did you decide to do that?
I was pushed from behind by my father, who was a medical doctor, and he wanted me to become a medical doctor also.
Are you still working in that?
Not at all. I'm working in areas of business now.
Are you happy you did that?
Yes, I am.
What's your dream job?
My dream job would be to be a missionary.
Really?
Yes.
Can you tell me about that?
My father's initial objective when he became an M.D. was to become a missionary, and he's a very generous person, and I think I am too. I got that from him herititarily. But I would like to help people, and I don't think being a doctor is helping people. I really don't. I think it's disingenuous to say you're helping people while you're stuffing wads of cash into your pocket. I would like to be building people homes and helping them find fresh water sources, things like that, if I could afford to travel to remote places like that.
Yeah. Sometimes when I'm feeling tense, I turn on the fish tank screen saver. Hey, I know it's not Hawaii, but it's the best I've got. What do you do to relax?
I exercise.
Okay. How are you at controlling your temper?
I think I'm pretty good at it. I think I'm pretty effective at it.
When was the last time you argued with someone, and what was it about?
It was probably two days ago. It was my girlfriend, and it was about her lack of consideration.
How did you feel in that moment?
Um, I felt frustrated.
Tell me about a situation that you wish you would handle differently.
A situation which I wished I could handle differently. In my later years, I would say I don't have many regrets. In my younger years, I used to be snubbed by people, and I would keep my mouth shut, and I wouldn't say anything. I would not express my displeasure of their actions or their behavior. I would just keep my mouth closed and internalize my feelings. I've learned that that is so wrong. And so in probably the last 15 to 20 years, I have made it a point to vocalize my displeasure with someone's actions right away, and that takes care of the anger immediately.
Has that gotten you in trouble?
Yes. It depends what you mean by trouble. I think all the way around, once you take the beginning to the end, it diffuses trouble rather than prolongs or protracts the trouble.
That makes sense. Tell me about the hardest decision you've ever had to make.
Going back, it would be to not to pursue medicine like my father wanted. We argued at length for many months and years about this, and finally I prevailed, and I didn't go that route. But that was probably the most difficult period in my life.
I see. Tell me about an event or something that you wish you could erase from your memory.
There was a time when I wished I could erase female interactions, girlfriends and their betrayals. But now I realize that keeping those memories make me who I am today, and dealing with them defines who I am today.
Tell me about your relationship with your family.
My parents are deceased. I had very good relationships with my parents. I'm very thankful for that. Even though my father was somewhat of a hard-handed draconian person, we came to an understanding well before he died. My brothers, I get along great with my younger brother, but my older brother has issues. He has psychological issues, and they continue to plague him and to affect me also, just knowing that he's going through turmoil.
I'm sorry. How do you cope with them?
Well, I guess I really don't cope with it because he's clinically depressed, and he has suicidal tendencies, and he's not working. He's very highly educated, and he doesn't talk to me, and his family is very abusive towards him. It's not a happy relationship for his family.
That sounds really hard.
Yes.
Who's someone that's been a positive influence in your life?
I would have to say my father. My father is my hero. He's my model. He's my archetype for what a man should be.
I understand. How easy is it for you to get a good night's sleep?
Tell me about the last time you felt really happy.
Oh, I was either surfing or snowboarding or rock climbing or mountain biking. I always experience joy when I'm exercising at a very high level of exertion.
That's so good to hear. How would your best friend describe you?
Funny, jovial, intelligent, perfectionist.
What are some things you wish you could change about yourself?
Maybe to submerge my hedonistic self.
Can you tell me about that?
I look at, once again, my father fills my consciousness. He was the ultimate deferrer of gratification. He put now behind him and he put what will be in the future in his sights and he never let go of that. And that's what made him the self-made man that he was.
Tell me about a time when someone made you feel really badly about yourself.
My last day of work when he fired me, he started using a lot of profanity toward me. I turned to him and I said, you cannot talk to me that way. He continued to use more profanity until I objected to it again and that's when he fired me. That's still in my mind and that occurred a year and a half ago.
Wow. Is there anything you regret?
Anything I regret? Oh yeah, I regret not getting married and having kids.
Could you have done anything to avoid it?
Sure, I suppose I could. But I think that would have robbed me of the many opportunities I had and I took to travel around the world and experience different cultures. Because that's what I enjoy the most about life is exploring and seeing different things and talking to different people and expanding my awareness. Because the United States is not the end of the world. Once you get to travel you find out that we do not have the highest level of living in the whole world. Other people think that we're the only ones that think that and I disagree.
I see what you mean. What advice would you give yourself 10 or 20 years ago?
That's a good one. I would say to just enjoy life because you never know when it's going to end and I think I've done that. And I may be coming to an end soon with this diagnosis of cancer. So I think I'm happy with my life thus far.
Tell me about something you did recently that you really enjoyed.
I was giving a rock climbing lesson. I have a part-time job of instructing rock climbing. And many of these people have never done it before. And they thanked me and they told me what a great time they had and how this may have changed their lives. So that was very gratifying to me.
That's great. What are you most proud of in your life?
I would say my devotion to the environment. I wasn't always an environmentalist. I have been vocal in the cause of being a steward of the environment. Because today there are a lot of people that are polluting the environment with a lot of chemicals and pollutants and septic things like that. And I stand up and I have been on TV and on YouTube speaking up against these people that pollute the environment.
Okay. I think I've announced everything on YouTube. Thanks for sharing your thoughts with me.
You're welcome. Goodbye.
Goodbye. That was interesting.

summary: During my divorce and after my mother passed away, I was diagnosed with depression. I experienced fatigue, a lack of enjoyment in anything, and a feeling of emptiness, loneliness, isolation, shock, and trauma. It was a very difficult time. Eventually, time helped me process everything. I used to see a therapist who was really helpful; she gave me a different perspective and listened to me, but I stopped going because I got busy with life. I do think therapy is useful, though, because I need someone to talk to. Lately, I've been feeling overwhelmed with school and everything else going on. To cope, I pray and go to church, which helps me stay grounded.
